text: hi everyone Symphony Tiano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new blur album
The Ballad of Darren this is a brand new
album from Old School UK Brit pop and
ALT rock outfit blur a band that peaked
in the 90s with records like Park life
13 and they're self-titled eventually
disbanding in the early 2000s with key
members such as Graham coxon and Damon
Albarn focusing on other projects and
solo work but they eventually did reform
in the 2010s dropping a record more than
10 years later the magic whip which the
issue with that record was that it was a
bit underwhelming didn't really live up
to the hype and just didn't have the
bite of the band's classic stuff it's
just sort of one of those mid-range
comeback albums that uh you know isn't
that thrilling isn't that exciting you
slowly forget about over time and now at
this point it's been almost a decade
again since that record yeah finally
getting a follow-up now making this one
of the slowest comebacks of all time
regardless though the band is back and
they're hitting us with a pretty
interesting one this time around I
wouldn't say The Ballad of Darren is a
return to form or anything like that it
definitely Embraces A moodier vibe that
is in line with the magic Whip and some
Damon Albarn solo stuff but in
comparison this album is much more
packed with beautiful ornate wondrous
instrumentation and Arrangements making
this possibly the most theatrical blur
album yet which is pretty Apparent from
the intro The Ballad and that very much
lives up to its name as it is pretty
much a very melancholy piano ballad with
lots of atmosphere surrounding it the
tune at the core of the track is solid
but again it's really those string hits
and that extra orchestral
instrumentation that really sells the
entire thing and brings in a serious
note of creativity and Oddity especially
some of the Melodies at the very end get
kind of swanky Vibe wise there's a
pretty hard contrast on the next track
St Charles square with its plotting and
monsters guitar riffs the whole thing
kind of feels like a mutant piece of
glam rock with some kooky wailing
background vocals kind of comes across
like a gorilla's piss take or like the
theme song to a Muppets Halloween
special and I mean that comparison in
the best way possible the Sinister
guitar leads are sick the pounding drums
work really well too and the lyrics are
pretty Eerie as well describing uh being
grabbed or pulled in by some kind of
monstrous figure and that monster serves
essentially as a metaphor for at least a
couple other things being haunted
loneliness then the track barbaric
brings another contrast with this song
being kind of a very sweet Carefree
piece of guitar pop with echoed riffs
that feel like something out of an 80s
Hard Rock Anthem think Thin Lizzy but uh
very pillowy and slowed down Damon's
vocals are very much still scratching a
moody itch on this one but the
background harmonies do a lot to sweeten
the deal not too much though because the
lyrics on the track especially toward
the end are absolutely crushing
meanwhile Russian strings is a very
David Bowie moment on the project with
its theatrical displays of Reverb drums
and guitars and keys Spotlight vocals
singing very gentle Melodies kind of
feels like floating in space like many
classic David Bowie tracks do and we get
more devastating lyrics on the track as
well the string is attached to all of us
there is nothing in the end only dust
when you pull the lever down I'll be
hitting the hard stuff so strong moments
on the record so far but I will say past
this point things do begin to Trail off
the Everglades isn't a bad acoustic
ballad but the issue is on this one
Damon albarn's vocals kind of succumb to
the heavy walls of instrumentation
seeping into the mix gradually wish they
popped a bit more even if I do think the
the crescendo of the song is kind of a
Powerhouse there's also the narcissist
which I wasn't crazy about as a single
in the context of the record though it
has grown on me quite a bit maybe
because it does effectively feel like a
bit of a pick-me-up moment moment in the
flow of the album as the group harmonies
are pretty entrancing the steady guitar
riffs pop a bit more than the endless
slates of gray during some parts of this
record from here though we move into a
pretty weak finish for the album on
goodbye Albert the vocals are so mushy
with effects or vocoder it kind of
renders the song
um you know pretty pretty boring really
Falls flat on its face nothing about
this track structurally or melodically
is as well groomed or put together as
anything in like the first leg of the
album far away Island though is a sort
of sweet Serene buzzing lullaby it does
bring a different vibe but it's not
exactly a show stopper instrumentally
there are slower moments on the record
that are two three times more beautiful
than this on Avalon we do get some very
unique and tense horn enhanced chord
progressions and that's certainly ear
grabbing but the tune at the core of
this track doesn't really stand out and
it's a shame because it is a unique
unique Arrangement just a memorable song
doesn't really come out of it then with
the closer blur brings forward a uh kind
of washed out ballad to end things and
you know it's far from my favorite song
here especially with Damon's vocal
sounding overcooked with effects once
again but at least the track does kind
of gradually get more intense and ends
things on a uh sort of over-the-top
moment it does bring at least some sense
of finality I guess and that's pretty
much the album it's a little short as
well for a record we've been waiting
this long for but I suppose that is made
up for by at least a few of the best
songs the band has released in a long
time and again some really great
orchestrations and arrangements as well
as some very heavy points of emotional
impact it is a sad album It's a record
that is really drowning in its fear in
its sorrow the issue is it just starts a
lot stronger than it finishes I'm
feeling a strong six to a light seven on
this one transition have you given this
record a listen did you love it did you
hate it what would you rate it you're
the best you're the best what should I
